question.title: Should consumers reading different topics in the same application belong to the same consumer group?
question.body:
I'm working on a Kafka-based Spring Boot application that reads from two Kafka topics: topicA and topicB. These topics carry completely unrelated data and are handled by different services within the same application.

A colleague insists that since both consumers live in the same application, they should belong to the same consumer group, because "one application = one consumer group".

However, I believe this is misleading. As far as I understand, a consumer group is used to distribute partitions of the same topic across multiple consumers, primarily for horizontal scaling.

In my case:

  • One consumer subscribes to one topicA, another - to multiple (topicGroupB)

  • The topics are unrelated and are not meant to be processed together.

  • The consumers are logically independent — they have different deserializers, business logic, and processing requirements.

The main disadvantage i see using the same group:

  • If one consumer fails, Kafka rebalances the entire group, causing unnecessary pause in the other consumer. - though, i'm not sure how much trouble it causes in real live.

  • There's no partition sharing between the two consumers anyway — they each read different topics.

Questions:

  • Is there any benefit in having two unrelated consumers (reading different topics) in the same consumer group, just because they live in the same application?

  • Are there any best practices or official recommendations (e.g., from Confluent or Apache Kafka) regarding this pattern?

P.S. it's Kafka, not Kafka streams
